text: Which of the following will give a precipitate with an aqueous solution of copper (I) chloride?
explanation:
A hydrocarbon that will produce a red precipitate when reacted with an aqueous solution of copper(I) chloride is an alkyne. More specifically, an alkyne with a terminal triple bond, like ethyne (acetylene), will react to form a red precipitate of copper(I) acetylide. The most reactive alkynes are those where the triple bond is at the end of the carbon chain (terminal triple bond).
There is an explanation video availablebelow.

text: The IUPAC name for CH\(_3\)CH\(_2\)COOCH\(_2\)CH\(_3\) is
explanation:
While naming the IUPAC nomenclature of hydrocarbon compounds, we usually start with the naming from the rare i.e the functional group from the right hand side.
Consider CH\(_3\)CH\(_2\)COOCH\(_2\)CH\(_3\), this is an ester obtained from two compounds propanoic acid and ethanol.
On splitting CH\(_3\)CH\(_2\)COOCH\(_2\)CH\(_3\), we have CH\(_3\)CH\(_2\)COO / CH\(_2\)CH\(_3\) dividing the compound into two; CH\(_3\)CH\(_2\)COO - Propanoate and CH\(_2\)CH\(_3\) - ethyl
So while naming as mentioned earlier on, we start the naming from the rare(RHS), and then the other(LHS). Thus, the name of the compound is; ethylpropanoate.
There is an explanation video availablebelow.

text: A certain hydrocarbon on complete combustion at s.t.p produced 89.6dm\(^3\) of CO\(_2\) and 54g of water. The hydrocarbon should be?
explanation:
C\(_x\)H\(_y\) + (x + y/4)O\(_2\) \(\to\) x CO\(_2\) + y/2 H\(_2\)O
89.6 dm\(^3\) \(\to\) x moles CO\(_2\)
22.4 dm\(^3\) \(\to\) 1 mole CO\(_2\)
x = \(\frac{89.6}{22.4}\)
= 4 moles CO\(_2\)
54g of H\(_2\)O \(\to\) k moles H\(_2\)O
18g H\(_2\)O \(\to\) 1 mole H\(_2\)O
k = \(\frac{54}{18}\)
= 3 moles H\(_2\)O
From the equation above,
x = 4
k = y/2 = 3
y/2 = 3 \(\implies\) y = 6
\(\therefore\) The hydrocarbon C\(_x\)H\(_y\) = C\(_4\)H\(_6\)
There is an explanation video availablebelow.

text: Hydrocarbons which will react with Tollen's reagent conform to the general formula
explanation:
Only hydrocarbons containing an aldehyde group (RCHO) or a terminal alkyne (R-C≡C-H) will react with Tollens' reagent, leading to a silver mirror formation or a white precipitate, respectively. Aldehydes are oxidized by Tollens' reagent (ammoniacal silver nitrate solution) to form carboxylic acids, while the silver ions (Ag+) are reduced to metallic silver (Ag), which deposits as a silver mirror on the walls of the test tube.
Terminal alkynes react with Tollens' reagent, producing a white precipitate of silver acetylide.

text:
Burning magnesium ribbon in air removes which of the following
(i) oxygen (ii) nitrogen (iii) argon and (iv) carbon(iv)oxide?

options.B: i, ii, iii and iv only

explanation:
The chemical reaction between magnesium ribbon and oxygen is a combustion reaction that produces magnesium oxide (MgO). Burning Magnesium ribbon in air removes oxygen, because as Magnesium burns in air, it reacts with oxygen in the air to form Magnesium oxide.
The chemical equation for this reaction is  2Mg(s)+O\(_2\)(g) → 2MgO(s)

text: Which of the following is the best starting material for the preparation of oxygen? Heating of trioxonitrate (v) with
explanation:
The best starting material for the preparation of oxygen through heating trioxonitrate(V) (nitrates) would involve a metal that facilitates the decomposition of the nitrate to produce oxygen, coincidentally, Pb (Lead) falls into that category.
Lead(II) nitrate (Pb(NO\(_3\))\(_2\)) decomposes upon heating to produce oxygen, nitrogen dioxide, and lead(II) oxide. This reaction is often used in laboratory settings to generate oxygen.
2Pb(NO\(_3\))\(_2\) → 2PbO + 4NO\(_2\) + O\(_2\)
This makes lead (Pb) a suitable choice for generating oxygen from nitrates.

text: SO\(_3\) is not directly dissolved in water in the industrial preparation of H\(_2\)SO\(_4\) by the contact process because

options.B: Acid is usually added to water and not water to acid
options.C: The reaction between SO\(_3\) and water is violently exothermic
options.D: SO\(_3\) does not dissolve readily in water

explanation:
Sulphur trioxide (SO\(_3\)) is not directly dissolved in water to produce sulphuric acid (H\(_2\)SO\(_4\)) because the reaction is highly exothermic and produces a fine mist of sulphuric acid, which is difficult to control and condense. Instead, SO\(_3\) is absorbed in concentrated sulphuric acid (oleum) to form oleum, which is then diluted with water to produce the desired sulphuric acid concentration.
There is an explanation video availablebelow.

text: Which of the following statements does not show Rutherford's account of Nuclear Theory? An atom contains a region

options.C: which is massive and can cause deflection of a few projectiles
options.D: which is very large and in which close to 98% of projectiles pass undeflected

explanation:
Rutherford's initial atomic model, though crucial for understanding the nucleus, didn't explicitly include neutrons. Rutherford's model, developed in 1911, identified a small, positively charged nucleus at the atom's center, but it only included positively charged protons within this nucleus. The neutral neutron was discovered later, by James Chadwick, in 1932.
Rutherford's experiment involved bombarding a thin layer of gold with alpha particles (helium nuclei). The results showed that most alpha particles passed through the gold foil with little deflection and a small fraction of alpha particles were deflected at large angles.
Rutherford's observations led him to propose the nuclear model of the atom, which states that:
1. Atoms have a small, dense, positively charged nucleus (containing most of the atom's mass).
2. The nucleus is surrounded by a cloud of electrons.
The deflection of alpha particles in Rutherford's experiment was indeed caused by the massive, positively charged nucleus. The nucleus's positive charge and concentrated mass led to the scattering of alpha particles at large angles. The nucleus is not described as "very large" in Rutherford's theory. Instead, it's the empty space surrounding the nucleus that's large, allowing most alpha particles to pass through with minimal deflection.
These also make option D incorrect, leaving us with option A and D as the answers, although more likely option D.

text: Elements X and Y have electronic configurations 1s\(^2\)2s\(^2\)2p\(^4\) and 1s\(^2\)2s\(^2\)2p\(^6\)3s\(^2\)3p\(^1\) respectively. When they combine, the formula of the compound formed is
explanation:
For better understanding, try to identify what elements X and Y are:
Elements X with electronic configurations: 1s\(^2\)2s\(^2\)2p\(^4\) is Oxygen (Adding the electrons together as 2+2+4= 8)
Elements Y with electronic configurations 1s\(^2\)2s\(^2\)2p\(^6\)3s\(^2\)3p\(^1\) is Aluminium ( Adding the electrons together as 2+2+6+2+1 = 13)
When Aluminium being a metal reacts with Oxygen being a non-metal, there is a transfer of electrons from metals to non-metals as 3 oxygen atoms reacts with 2 Aluminium atoms thereby forming Al\(_2\)O\(_3\) ⇒ Y\(_2\)X\(_3\).
There is an explanation video availablebelow.

text: By what amount must the temperature of 200cm\(^3\) of Nitrogen at 27°C be increased to double the pressure if the final volume is 150cm\(^3\) (Assume ideality)
explanation:
Parameters given:
V\(_1\) = 200 cm\(^3\); T\(_1\) = 27 + 273 = 300K.
V\(_2\) = 150 cm\(^3\); T\(_2\) = ?
P\(_2\) = 2P\(_1\).
Using the Ideal Gas Equation:
\(\frac{P_1 V_1}{T_1} = \frac{P_2 V_2}{T_2}\)
\(\frac{P_1 \times 200}{300} = \frac{2P_1 \times 150}{T_2}\)
\(\frac{2}{3} = \frac{300}{T_2}\)
T\(_2\) = 450K.
= 450K - 273K
= 177°C
177 - 27 = 150
That is the amount by which T1 must be increased.
There is an explanation video availablebelow.

text:
The combustion of carbon(II)oxide in oxygen can be represented by equation:
         2CO + O\(_2\) → 2CO\(_2\)
Calculate the volume of the resulting mixture at the end of the reaction, if 50cm\(^3\) of carbon(ii)oxide was exploded in 100cm\(^3\) of oxygen
explanation:
2CO + O\(_2\) → 2CO\(_2\)
From the equation, we see that  2 volumes of CO react with 1 volume of O\(_2\) to produce 2 volumes of CO\(_2\).
Given:
Volume of CO = 50 cm³
Volume of O\(_2\) = 100 cm³
First, let's find the limiting reactant:
CO: 50 cm³ / 2 = 25 cm³ of O\(_2\) required (based on the stoichiometry)
However, we were told that 50cm\(^3\) of carbon(II)oxide was exploded in 100cm\(^3\) of oxygen, which means Oxygen is in excess (100 cm³ ), then CO is the limiting reactant, it will be completely consumed.
Now, let's calculate the volume of CO\(_2\)` produced:
50 cm³ of CO produces 50 cm³ of CO\(_2\) i.e  (1:1 ratio)
The resulting mixture will contain 50 cm³ of CO\(_2\) and the remaining O\(_2\) (100 cm³ - 25 cm³ ) = 75 cm³
Total volume of the resulting mixture = Volume of product (CO\(_2\)) + Volume of the remaining O\(_2\)
= 50 cm\(^3\) +  75 cm\(^3\)
= 125 cm\(^3\)
So, the volume of the resulting mixture at the end of the reaction is 125 cm³.
There is an explanation video availablebelow.

text:
Consider the reaction
A\(_{(s)}\) + 2B\(_{(g)}\) → 2C\(_{(aq)}\) + D\(_{(g)}\)
What will be the effect of a decrease in pressure on the reaction?

options.B: rate of forward reaction will increase
options.C: rate of backward reaction will increase
options.D: rates of forward and backward reaction are not affected

explanation:
Given: The equation belowA\(_{(s)}\) + 2B\(_{(g)}\) → 2C\(_{(aq)}\) + D\(_{(g)}\)
According to Le Chatelier's Principle:
Pressure changes affects only the gaseous reactants and productsThere must be different amount of gaseous particles on both sides.
Generally; a decrease in the pressure shifts the equilibrium position in favor of the side with larger volume of gases.
I.e  rates of backward reaction.
NB: This is a correction to the video explanation.
There is an explanation video availablebelow.

This color change arises because the aldehyde can be oxidized to the corresponding carboxylic acid.

text: Which of the following statements about catalyst is false?

options.B: catalyst do not appear in the balanced equation
options.C: catalyst reduce the activation energy for a reaction
options.D: catalysts do not alter the mechanism of the reaction and never appear in the rate low

explanation:
Option D says catalysts do not alter the mechanism of the reaction and never appear in the rate low. This statement is false; catalysts do alter the mechanism of a reaction by providing an alternative pathway with a lower activation energy, and while they do not appear in the overall balanced chemical equation, they can be involved in individual steps of the reaction mechanism, meaning they may appear in the rate law for a specific step of the reaction.

text:
At 27°C, 58.5g of sodium chloride is present in 250cm\(^3\) of a solution. The solubility of sodium chloride at this temperature is?
(molar mass of sodium chloride = 111.0gmol\(^{-1}\))
explanation:
Given the Mass of the salt = 58.5g
Volume = 250 cm\(^3\) = 0.25 dm\(^3\)
Mass concentration = \(\frac{Mass}{Volume}\)
= \(\frac{58.5}{0.25}\) = 234 gdm\(^{-3}\)
Solubility (in moldm\(^{-3}\) = \(\frac{234}{111} \)
= 2.11 moldm\(^{-3}\)
\(\approxeq\) 2.0 moldm\(^{-3}\)

text: A radioactive nucleus has a half-life of 20 years, starting with 100,000 particles, how many particles will be left exactly at the end of 40 years
explanation:
Given:
t\(_{\frac{1}{2}\) = 20 years
After the first 20 years, half of the substance (\(\frac{1}{2} \times 100,000 = 50,000\)) will have decayed. Hence, we have 100,000 - 50,000 = 50,000 particles left.
After the second 20 years (being 40 years in all), half of the remaining substance (\(\frac{1}{2} \times 50,000 = 25,000\)) will have decayed.
Remaining particles after 40 years = 50,000 - 25,000
= 25,000 particles.
There is an explanation video availablebelow.

text:
Consider the equation below:
Cr\(_2\)O\(_7 ^{2-}\) + 6Fe\(^{2+}\) + 14H\(^{+}\) \(\to\) 2Cr\(^{3+}\) + 6Fe\(^{3+}\) + 7H\(_2\)O.
The oxidation number of chromium changes from
explanation:
Cr\(_2\)O\(_7 ^{2-}\) + 6Fe\(^{2+}\) + 14H\(^{+}\) \(\to\) 2Cr\(^{3+}\) + 6Fe\(^{3+}\) + 7H\(_2\)O
The oxidation of Cr in Cr\(_2\)O\(_7 ^{2-}\) :
Let the oxidation of Cr = x;
2x + (-2 x 7) = -2 \(\implies\) 2x - 14 = -2
2x = 12 ; x = +6
Hence, the change in oxidation of Cr = +6 to +3

text: In the reaction between sodium hydroxide and tetraoxosulphate (VI) solutions, what volume of 0.5 molar sodium hydroxide would exactly neutralize 10cm\(^3\) of 1.25 molar tetraoxosulphate (vi) acid?
explanation:
Equation of reaction : 2NaOH + H\(_2\)SO\(_4\) → Na\(_2\)SO\(_4\) + 2H\(_2\)OConcentration of a base, CB = 0.5MVolume of acid, V\(_A\) = 10cm\(^3\)Concentration of an acid, C\(_A\) = 1.25MVolume of base, V\(_B\) = ?Recall:
\(\frac{C_A V_A}{C_B V_B} = \frac{n_A}{n_B}\) ... (1)
N.B: From the equation,
\(\frac{n_A}{n_B} = \frac{1}{2}\)From (1)
\(\frac{1.25 \times 10}{0.5 \times V_B} = \frac{1}{2}\)
\(\frac{12.5}{0.5V_B} = \frac{1}{2}\)
25 = 0.5V\(_B\)VB = 50.0 cm\(^3\)

text:
A compound contains 40.0% carbon, 6.7% hydrogen and 53.3% oxygen. If the molar mass of the compound is 180. Find the molecular formula.
[H = 1, C = 12, O = 16]
explanation:
C → 40/12 ≈ 3
H → 6.7/1 ≈ 6
O → 53.3/16 ≈ 3
dividing through with the lowest value, 3
C\(_1\)H\(_2\)O\(_1\)
[C\(_1\)H\(_2\)O\(_1\)]n = 180
[12 + 2 + 16]m = 180
30n = 180
n = 6
:C\(_6\)H\(_12\)O\(_6\)

text:
What mass of magnesium would be obtained by passing a current of 2 amperes for 2 hours 30 mins, through molten magnesium chloride?
[1 faraday = 96500C, Mg = 24]
explanation:
Given  Data:
Time (T) = 2hrs 30mins
where 2hrs =120mins
2hrs & 30mins = (120 + 30)mins = 150mins
150mins to Seconds = 150 x60 = 9,000s
Q = I x T
2 x 9,000 =18,000
where mg has valency of +2
So 2 x 96500 will discharge 24g of mg
and 18,000 will discharge xg of mg
2 x 96500 =24
18,000 =x
x = \(\frac{24 \times 18,000}{2 x 96500}\)
≈ 2.00g
There is an explanation video availablebelow.

text:

Given:
V = ? ,  C = 0.100M,   m = 5g
Molar mass, M of NaNO\(_3\) = 23 + 14 + (16 X 3) = 85 g/mol
Number of moles, n = \(\frac{mass}{Molar Mass}\)
=  \(\frac{5}{85}\)
n = 0.0588 mole
Recall that            n = \(\frac{CV}{1000}\)
n = CV (looking through the options, no need including the 1000 since the answer was left in Litres)
V = \(\frac{n}{C}\)
V =   \(\frac{0.0588}{0.100}\)
V =  0.588 Litres

explanation:

text: The shapes of water, ammonia, carbon (iv) oxide and methane are respectively
explanation:
Ammonia \((NH_3\)) has a trigonal pyramidal structure with a bond angle of approximately 107 degrees. Methane (\(CH_4\)) has a tetrahedral structure with a bond angle of 109.5 degrees.Carbon dioxide is a linear molecule,with a 180-degree bond angle. Water \((H_2O\)) has a bent or V-shaped structure with a bond angle of approximately 104.5 degrees.

text: Which quantum divides shells into orbitals?
explanation:
The azimuthal quantum number determines an atom's orbital angular momentum and the shape of the orbital. The principal quantum number determines its number of shells. Magnetic quantum number determines how many orbitals there are as well as their orientation within a subshell.
There is an explanation video availablebelow.

text: The oxidation state(s) of nitrogen in ammonium nitrite is/are
explanation:
Ammonium nitrite = NH\(_4\)NO\(_2\)
NH\(_4 ^+\): Let the oxidation number of Nitrogen = x
x + 4 = 1 \(\implies\) x = 1 - 4
x = -3
NO\(_2 ^-\): x - 4 = -1
x = -1 + 4 \(\implies\) x = +3.
The oxidation numbers for Nitrogen in Ammonium Nitrite = -3, +3.
There is an explanation video availablebelow.

text: Hydrogen bond is a sort of
explanation: Hydrogen bonding is a type of Van der Waals force, specifically a strong dipole-dipole interaction. It's a distinct type of intermolecular attraction, not a covalent bond, though it's stronger than most other Van der Waals forces like London dispersion forces.

text: Methane is prepared in the laboratory by heating a mixture of sodium ethanoate with soda lime. The chemical constituent(s) of soda lime is/are

Soda lime is a mixture of caustic soda (NaOH) and lime water (Ca(OH)\(_2\)).

text: Which of the following sets of operation will completely separate a mixture of sodium chloride, sand and iodine?

options.A: addition of water, filtration, evaporation to dryness and sublimation
options.B: filtration, evaporation to dryness, addition of water and sublimation
options.C: sublimation, filtration, evaporation and addition of water
options.D: sublimation, addition of water, filtration and evaporation to dryness

explanation:
Process:
Add water to the mixture and then filter. The resultant is a salt solution as your filtrate and a mixture of iodine and sand as your residue. Evaporate the filtrate to dryness to get your sodium chloride (salt). Heat the residue to sublime the iodine from the sand.
Addition of water \(\to\) Filtration \(\to\) Evaporation \(\to\) Sublimation.
There is an explanation video availablebelow.

text: 200cm\(^3\) of 0.50mol/dm\(^3\) solution of calcium hydrogen trioxocarbonate (IV) is heated. The maximum weight of solid precipitated is
explanation:
Equation: Ca(HCO\(_3\))\(_2\) \(\to\) CaCO\(_3\) (precipitate) + H\(_2\)O + CO\(_2\) (in the presence of heat)
V = 200 cm\(^3\) = 0.2 dm\(^3\)
C = 0.5 mol/dm\(^3\) = 0.5M
N = CV \(\implies\) N = 0.5 \(\times\) 0.2
= 0.1 mole
From the equation 1 mole of Ca(HCO\(_3\))\(_2\) gives 100g of CaCO\(_3\)
(1 mole CaCO\(_3\) = 40 + 12 + (3 x 16) = 100g\)
0.1 mole of Ca(HCO\(_3\))\(_2\) gives x g of CaCO\(_3\).
\(\frac{1}{0.10} = \frac{100}{x}\)
\(x = 100 \times 0.10 = 10 g\)
There is an explanation video availablebelow.

text: Which of the following conditions will most enhance the spontaneity of a reaction?

options.A: \(\Delta\)H is negative and greater than T\(\Delta\)S
options.C: \(\Delta\)H is positive and less than T\(\Delta\)S
options.D: \(\Delta\)H is positive and equal to T\(\Delta\)S

explanation:
A reaction is spontaneous when the Gibbs free energy change (ΔG) is negative. This is determined by the equation ΔG = ΔH - TΔS, where ΔH is the enthalpy change, T is the temperature, and ΔS is the entropy change. Therefore, a reaction is spontaneous if ΔH is negative and TΔS is negative, or if ΔH is positive and TΔS is positive and greater than ΔH. In other words, for a reaction to be spontaneous, the decrease in enthalpy (ΔH) must be greater than the increase in entropy (TΔS).
In summary: For a reaction to be spontaneous, either ΔH must be negative (exothermic) and TΔS must be smaller than ΔH, or TΔS must be positive and larger than ΔH. The key is to ensure that the decrease in Gibbs free energy (ΔG < 0) is negative.
Applying values to those parameters, options A, B and C appear correct because they'll all make ΔG negative but the one that will mostly enhance spontaneity is option A because ΔG = -ve, ΔH = - ve.
There is an explanation video availablebelow.

text: X is a substance which liberates CO\(_2\) on treatment with concentrated H\(_2\)SO\(_4\). A warm solution of X can decolorize acidified KMnO\(_4\). X is
explanation:
It should be noted that for X to liberate CO\(_2\), X must be a carbonate or an oxalate. Since X decolorizes KMnO\(_4\), X must be an oxalate.
Therefore, X is H\(_2\)C\(_2\)O\(_4\).
There is an explanation video availablebelow.

text: The velocity, V of a gas is related to its mass, M by (k = proportionality constant)
explanation:
Recall:
V = \(\sqrt{\frac{3RT}{M}}\)
\(\therefore V \propto \frac{1}{\sqrt{M}}\)
\(V = \frac{k}{\sqrt{M}}\)
V = \(\frac{k}{M^{\frac{1}{2}}}\)
There is an explanation video availablebelow.

text: The emission of two successive beta particles from the nucleus \(^{32} _{15} P\) will produce
Hydrogen diffused through a porous plug

options.B: at the same speed as oxygen
options.C: four times as fast as oxygen

explanation:
Using Graham's Law of Diffusion,
\(\frac{R_1}{R_2} = \sqrt{\frac{m_2}{m_1}}\)
\(\frac{R_H}{R_O} = \sqrt{\frac{m_O}{m_H}}\)
\(\frac{R_H}{R_O} = \sqrt{\frac{32}{2}}\)
\(\frac{R_H}{R_O} = \sqrt{16} = 4\)
\(\therefore R_H = 4 \times R_O\)
Therefore, hydrogen diffuses 4 times faster than oxygen.
There is an explanation video availablebelow.

text:
If the cost of electricity required to discharge 10g of an ion X\(^{3+}\) is N20.00, how much would it cost to discharge 6g of ion Y\(^{2+}\)?
[1 faraday = 96,500C, atomic masses are X = 27, Y = 24]
explanation:
X\(^{3+}\) + 3e\(^-\) \(\to\) X
3F = 27g
xF = 10g
\(\frac{x}{3} = \frac{10}{27} \implies x = \frac{10}{9} F\)
\(\frac{10}{9}\)F \(\equiv\) N20.00
1F is equivalent to x
\(\frac{1}{\frac{10}{9}} = \frac{x}{20}\)
\(\frac{9}{10} = \frac{x}{20} \implies x = N18.00\)
1F is equivalent to N18.00.
Y\(^{2+}\) + 2e\(^-\) \(\to\) Y
2F = 24g
xF = 6g
x = \(\frac{6 \times 2}{24} = \frac{1}{2} F\)
1F = N18.00
\(\frac{1}{2}\)F = \(\frac{1}{2} \times N18.00\)
= N9.00
There is an explanation video availablebelow.

text:
The cost of discharging 6.0g of a divalent metal, X from its salt is ₦12.00. What is the cost of discharging 9.0g of a trivalent metal, Y from its salt under the same condition?
[X = 63, Y = 27, 1F = 96,500C]
explanation:
For X:  X\(^{2+}\) + 2e\(^-\) \(\to\) X
2F = 63g
xF = 6g
x = \(\frac{6 \times 2}{63} = \frac{4}{21} F\)
\(\frac{4}{21}\)F = N12.00
1F = \(\frac{12}{\frac{4}{21}}\)
= N63.00
1F is equivalent to N63.00.
For Y: Y\(^{3+}\) + 3e\(^-\) \(\to\) Y
3F = 27g
xF = 9g
x = \(\frac{3 \times 9}{27}\)
= 1F
1F = N63.00
There is an explanation video availablebelow.

text: How many electrons will be found in the nucleus of an atom with mass number 23 and 17 neutrons?
explanation:
Electrons are found in the orbit of the atom. They revolve around the nucleus. There's no electron found in the nucleus of an atom.

text: An element Z contains 80% of \(^{16} _8\)Z and 20% of \(^{18} _8\)Z. Its relative atomic mass is
explanation:
R.A.M of Z = \(16(\frac{80}{100}) + 18(\frac{20}{100})\)
= \(12.8 + 3.6\)
= 16.4

text: The part of the total energy of a system that accounts for the useful work done in a system is known as
explanation:
Gibb's free energy is the fraction of the total energy of a system that accounts for how much useful work can be done in a system.

text:
Which of the following factors will speed up the rate of evolution of carbon (iv) oxide in the reaction below?
2HCl + CaCO\(_3\) → CaCl\(_2\) + H\(_2\)O + CO\(_2\)

options.A: Increasing the concentration of the acid
options.B: Increasing the surface area of CaCO\(_3\)
options.D: Reducing the concentration of the acid

explanation:
The following factors increase a reaction rate- Increase in concentration of reactants- Increase in temperature- Addition of catalyst- Increase in the surface area of reactant(s)
